revision.text:
{{short description|Wikipedia list article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}} {{Use British English|date=September 2011}} Listed below are the [[Nobel laureate]]s born in [[Wales]], in alphabetical order. Wales is a country within the [[United Kingdom]], this means that [[Welsh people|Welsh]] Nobel laureates are included in the list of Nobel laureates for [[Great Britain]] by the [[Nobel Foundation]].
Wales has a population of approximately 3 million people.<ref name="Barwell2009">{{cite book|author=Richard Barwell|title=Multilingualism in Mathematics Classrooms: Global Perspectives|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LzDXBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA113|year=2009|publisher=Multilingual Matters|isbn=978-1-84769-204-7|pages=113–|quote=With a population of around 3 million, Wales is one of the smallest of the four nations that make up the United Kingdom. }}</ref> On a [[per capita]] basis the number of Nobel laureates compares favourably with other leading Nobel Prize-winning countries.<ref name="AU">[http://www.dfat.gov.au/facts/nobel_prize_winners.html/ Australian Nobel Prize winners] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110219181727/http://dfat.gov.au/facts/nobel_prize_winners.html |date=19 February 2011 }} Australian Government web site. URL referred on 5 September 2010</ref>
== Nobel laureates ==
=== Sir Clive Granger ===
Sir [[Clive Granger]] (4 September 1934 – 27 May 2009) was born in [[Swansea]] and was awarded the [[Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences]] in 2003, sharing the prize with [[Robert F. Engle]].<ref name="WOL">[http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/wales-news/2007/10/09/previous-welsh-nobel-prize-winners-91466-19923195/ Previous Welsh Nobel Prize winners] Wales On Line web site. URL referred 5 September 2010</ref>
=== Brian David Josephson ===
[[Brian David Josephson]] is a Welsh physicist best known for his pioneering work on [[superconductivity]] and [[quantum tunnelling]] who was born in 1940 in [[Cardiff]] and won the [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] in 1973 for the prediction of the [[Josephson effect]].<ref name="WOL" />
=== Bertrand Russell ===
The [[philosopher]] [[Bertrand Russell]] (18 May 1872 – February 1970) won the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] in 1950 ‘in recognition of his varied and significant writings in which he champions [[humanitarian]] ideals and [[freedom of thought]]’.<ref name="Nobel2">[http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1950/russell-bio.html/ Nobel Prize literature laureates] Nobel Prize Foundation web site. URL referred 5 September 2010</ref> He was born in [[Trellech]], [[Monmouthshire]], spent most of his time outside Wales, and died at his home at Plas Penrhyn, [[Penrhyndeudraeth]], [[Merionethshire]].
=== Sir Martin Evans ===
[[Sir Martin John Evans]] {{postnominals|country=GBR|FRS|FMedSci}} (born 1 January 1941, [[Stroud]], [[Gloucestershire]]) is a Welsh scientist who, with [[Matthew Kaufman]], was the first to culture mice [[embryonic stem cell]]s and cultivate them in a laboratory in 1981. He is also known, along with [[Mario Capecchi]] and [[Oliver Smithies]], for his work in the development of the [[knockout mouse]] and the related technology of [[gene targeting]], a method of using embryonic stem cells to create specific gene modifications in mice. In 2007, the three shared the [[Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine]] in recognition of their discovery and contribution to the efforts to develop new treatments for illnesses in humans.
